Key Arguments: The Proposed Bill does not go far enough to address the threat of misinformation and disinformation to Australian democracy.
The reliance on industry to create voluntary codes of practice is insufficient.
Carveouts, such as for 'professional news content', undermine the purpose of the legislation.
There should be a blanket prohibition on the knowing dissemination of misinformation and disinformation.
The expression 'adequate protection' should be clearly defined.
Section 48 is too prescriptive and should allow more discretion for ACMA.
Section 35(2)(c) should be deleted to prevent misinformation in electoral matters.
An actionable private right should be created against entities that misinform or disinform.
The definition of 'excluded content for misinformation purposes' should consider the purpose of dissemination.
Links to misinformative or disinformative content should be addressed in the legislation.
Main Themes: Insufficiency of current and proposed regulatory frameworks
Need for stricter regulations and penalties
Importance of clear definitions and discretionary powers for ACMA
Advocacy for private rights of action against misinformation
Notable Quotes: Misinformation and disinformation pose an existential threat to Australian democracy.
The Proposed Bill leaves too much up for self-regulation.
There needs to be a real, possibly existential threat to any entity that would seek to undermine the Australian political discourse through misinformation or disinformation.
